questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Targeted biopsy

 

A targeted biopsy (punch biopsy) is the next line of management in the above case as the patient is symptomatic (postcoital bleeding) and has a visible lesion. This approach allows for the direct sampling of the lesion to assess for malignancy or other pathological changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conisation: Conisation is an excisional procedure that is typically performed once biopsy-proven cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 and 3) is diagnosed. It is not the initial step for a visible mass with postcoital bleeding.

 

Option B. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure used for treating CIN1 or 2. It is not suitable for initial diagnosis or for lesions suspected of being malignant.

 

Option D. Pap smear: A Pap smear is done when there are symptoms with no identifiable lesion. It is a screening tool and not diagnostic for a visible lesion with postcoital bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a symptomatic patient with a visible cervical lesion and postcoital bleeding, a targeted biopsy is the appropriate next step to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

 

Ref: Page 327, DC Dutta’a Textbook of gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A female presents to OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complaints of bleeding per vagina and mild abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive and hCG level is 2800 IU/L. On investigation, mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single-dose methotrexate injection

 

The clinical scenario presented indicates an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. The patient is hemodynamically stable, and the hCG level is 2800 IU/L with an adnexal mass measuring 3 x 2 cm. These findings meet the criteria for medical management of an ectopic pregnancy with methotrexate. Single-dose methotrexate injection is an appropriate treatment choice for an unruptured ectopic pregnancy when the patient is stable, has no significant symptoms, and the gestational sac is less than 3.5 cm in size without visible cardiac activity. Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis and cell replication, effectively treating the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral methotrexate: Oral methotrexate is not a standard treatment protocol for ectopic pregnancy. Methotrexate for ectopic pregnancy is typically administered via injection to ensure proper dosage and effectiveness.

 

Option C. Serial methotrexate + leucovorin rescue: This multidose protocol is used for ectopic pregnancies with higher hCG levels or when the single-dose protocol is contraindicated or has failed. However, it is more complex and involves multiple injections and monitoring.

 

Option D. Salpingectomy: Surgical management, such as salpingectomy, is indicated for ectopic pregnancies with significant pain, adnexal masses larger than 35 mm, visible fetal heartbeat, or serum hCG levels of 5000 IU/L or more. In this case, the patient’s condition does not meet these criteria, making surgery unnecessary.

 

Management of Unruptured Ectopic

 

 

Surgical Management in Unruptured Ectopic –

 

Indicated in:

 

  1. an ectopic pregnancy and significant pain
  2. an ectopic pregnancy with an adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger
  3. an ectopic pregnancy with a fetal heartbeat visible on an ultrasound scan
  4. an ectopic pregnancy and a serum hCG level of 5,000 IU/L or more

 

 Laparoscopy is preferred

 

  1. SALPINGECTOMY: Preferred if:
    • Extensive tubal involvement/ damage
    • Recurrent ectopic pregnancy in the same tube
    • Completed family
    • Ectopic at the site of a previous tubal sterilization
  2. SALPINGOSTOMY: (Linear incision on the antimesenteric border with removal of products of conception) Done if a woman wants to conceive in the future.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy in a hemodynamically stable patient with an hCG level less than 5000 IU/L and an adnexal mass smaller than 3.5 cm is typically treated with a single-dose methotrexate injection.

questions.text: The most potent natural estrogen is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estradiol

 

Estrogens play a crucial role in the development and regulation of the female reproductive system and secondary sexual characteristics. Among the natural estrogens, estradiol is the most potent. Estradiol is primarily produced by the ovaries and is the predominant estrogen during the reproductive years of a woman. It has the highest affinity for estrogen receptors, making it the most effective at eliciting estrogenic responses in the body.

 

Estrone, on the other hand, is the main estrogen found in postmenopausal women and is less potent than estradiol. Estriol is the weakest of the three natural estrogens and is predominantly produced during pregnancy. Conjugated equine estrogen is a mixture of estrogens derived from the urine of pregnant mares and is less potent than estradiol.

 

Therefore, estradiol is considered the most potent natural estrogen due to its strong affinity for estrogen receptors and its significant role in reproductive physiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrone: Although it is a natural estrogen, estrone is less potent than estradiol. It is primarily found in postmenopausal women and does not exert the same level of estrogenic activity as estradiol.

 

Option C. Estriol: This estrogen is the least potent of the natural estrogens and is mainly produced during pregnancy. It has a much lower affinity for estrogen receptors compared to estradiol.

 

Option D. Conjugated equine estrogen: This is a semi-synthetic mixture of estrogens obtained from horses. While it is used in hormone replacement therapy, its potency is lower than that of estradiol and it is not considered a single natural estrogen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is the most potent natural estrogen, especially during a woman’s reproductive years, due to its high receptor affinity and significant physiological effects

choices.text: 10% buffered formalin
95% ethyl alcohol
None of the above

questions.text: Fixative for PAP smear: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 95% ethyl alcohol

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol. This fixative preserves the cellular detail necessary for accurate cytological evaluation by preventing cellular autolysis and degradation. The use of 95% ethyl alcohol ensures that the cells maintain their morphology, which is critical for detecting abnormalities such as dysplasia or carcinoma.

 

  • 95% Ethyl Alcohol: This is the standard fixative for Pap smears, ensuring optimal preservation of cellular details.
  • Ethanol Spray: In modern practice, an ethanol spray fixative is available, which can be conveniently used in an office setting to fix the smear immediately after it is taken.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10% buffered formalin: This fixative is typically used for histological specimens rather than cytological smears like the Pap test.

 

Option C. Air dried: Air drying is not recommended for Pap smears as it can cause cellular distortion and artifacts, which complicate the interpretation of the smear.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as 95% ethyl alcohol is the correct fixative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol, which preserves cellular morphology necessary for accurate cytological evaluation.

 

Ref: Page no 271, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Previous manual removal of the placenta

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman visits her obstetrician for a routine prenatal appointment at 20 weeks of gestation. Which of the following factors would not automatically categorize her current pregnancy as high-risk?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Previous manual removal of the placenta


Previous manual removal of the placenta, although a significant event, does not automatically place subsequent pregnancies in the high-risk category unless it is associated with other conditions such as uterine scarring, placenta accreta, or other complications. High-risk pregnancies are typically defined by factors that pose a significant risk to the mother or fetus, including chronic health conditions, certain pregnancy-related complications, or lifestyle factors.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Multiple pregnancy: Pregnancies involving more than one fetus (e.g., twins or triplets) are automatically considered high-risk due to the increased likelihood of complications such as preterm birth, pre-eclampsia, and fetal growth restriction.

 

Option C. Pre-eclampsia: A pregnancy disorder characterized by high blood pressure and signs of damage to another organ system, often the kidneys. It significantly increases the risk for both the mother and fetus, including the risk of preterm delivery and placental abruption.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes mellitus: This condition occurs when a woman develops high blood glucose levels during pregnancy. It can lead to complications such as macrosomia (large for gestational age baby), increased risk of cesarean delivery, and future risk of type 2 diabetes for both the mother and child.

 

Educational Objective:


High-risk pregnancies are defined by factors that increase the risk of complications for the mother or fetus, such as chronic health conditions, pregnancy-specific disorders, and certain lifestyle factors. Previous manual removal of the placenta does not automatically classify a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk unless associated with other complications.

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks of gestation presents for routine evaluation. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 24 weeks. Ultrasonography revealed decreased amniotic fluid. Which of the following conditions would have led to this presentation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

  • Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like:
    • Bilateral renal agenesis: Absence of both kidneys, leading to a lack of urine production, which is a major component of amniotic fluid.
    • Bilateral dysplastic kidneys: Kidneys that do not function properly, also leading to reduced urine output.
    • Bilateral autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease: This genetic disorder causes the kidneys to develop cysts, impairing their function.
    • Complex genito-urinary anomalies: Conditions like persistent cloaca and sirenomelia can affect kidney and urinary tract development, leading to oligohydramnios.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal Fistula: Tracheoesophageal fistula typically leads to polyhydramnios due to an obstruction to swallowing, resulting in an accumulation of amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Cardiac Abnormalities: Cardiac abnormalities usually lead to cardiac failure, which can result in fetal hydrops and polyhydramnios due to fluid accumulation in various fetal compartments.

 

Option D. Ureteral Stricture: Ureteral stricture will not lead to oligohydramnios unless there is bilateral involvement, which would be less common than the systemic impact of renal agenesis or other significant renal anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be caused by renal anomalies, with bilateral renal agenesis being a primary condition leading to reduced amniotic fluid levels.

 

Ref: Page no 670, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrectly matched? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystocele - Colposuspension

 

Anterior colporrhaphy is performed for cystocele.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cystocele, the appropriate surgical management is anterior colporrhaphy, not colposuspension.

choices.text: Placenta membranacea
Placenta succenturiata
Circumvallate placenta

questions.text: A pregnant woman delivered a baby with the normal expulsion of an intact placenta. After half an hour she started bleeding per vaginal. On examination, she was hypotensive, and a boggy mass was palpated per abdomen. Ultrasound showed retained placental tissues. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Placenta succenturiate

 

  • It is mentioned here that the placenta expelled looked normal and intact
  • In such a case, if there is a retained component, it could be a succenturiate lobe
  • Placenta succenturiata refers to a placenta with an additional lobe/lobes of placental tissue located a few centimeters away.
  • The ancillary lobes can be associated with complications such as placenta previa, vasa previa, postpartum hemorrhage or infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta membranacea:

 

  • Placenta membranacea is a rare placental disorder characterized by the presence of fetal membranes (complete or partially) covered by chorionic villi.
  • Associated with painless vaginal bleeding in the second and third trimester
  • This condition can be associated with other placental abnormalities, such as placenta previa or accreta.
  • Perinatal outcome may include stillbirth, preterm delivery, or neonatal death.

 

 

Option C. Circummarginate placenta:

 

  • Uncommon variation in placental morphology in which a thin fibrous ring is present at the margin of the chorionic plate where the fetal vessels appear to terminate.
  • The placenta is unduly large and thin. The placenta not only develops from the chorion frondosum but also from the chorion laeve so that the whole of the ovum is practically covered by the placenta
  • Associated with Abortion, Hydrorrhea gravidarum (excessive watery vaginal discharge), Antepartum hemorrhage, Growth retardation of the baby, Preterm delivery and Retained placenta or membranes.

 

 

Option D. Circumvallate placenta:

 

  • The fetal surface is divided into a central depressed zone surrounded by a thickened white ring which is usually complete.
  • The ring is situated at varying distances from the margin of the placenta. The ring is composed of a double fold of amnion and chorion with degenerated decidua (vera) and fibrin in between
  • Vessels radiate from the cord insertion as far as the ring and then disappear from view
  • The peripheral zone outside the ring is thicker and the edge is elevated and rounded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta succenturiata is characterized by an additional lobe of placental tissue separate from the main placenta, which can be retained postpartum, leading to hemorrhage and requiring careful monitoring and management.

 

Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)
Functional ovarian cyst
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for progression to borderline ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nulliparity

 

Nulliparity is associated with a slightly increased risk of ovarian tumors, including borderline ovarian tumors, possibly due to uninterrupted ovulation and hormonal fluctuations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are known to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.

 

Option B. Functional ovarian cyst: Functional ovarian cysts typically do not progress to ovarian tumors.

 

Option D. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS): Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) has not been strongly linked with increased risk of borderline ovarian tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nulliparity is recognized as a risk factor for borderline ovarian tumors, highlighting the influence of reproductive factors on ovarian health.

choices.text: Contraction stress test

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of fetal biophysical profile? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Contraction stress test

 

The fetal biophysical profile (BPP) is a comprehensive assessment used to evaluate fetal well-being, and it includes five components:

 

  1. NST (Non-Stress Test): Evaluates fetal heart rate reactivity.
  2. Amniotic Fluid Volume (AFV): Assessed through ultrasound to check the amount of amniotic fluid.
  3. Fetal Movement: Observes fetal movements through ultrasound.
  4. Fetal Tone: Evaluates the presence of fetal muscle tone and limb movements.
  5. Fetal Breathing: Assesses the presence and duration of fetal breathing movements.

 

The Contraction Stress Test (CST) is not part of the BPP. Instead, it is a separate test used to assess the fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions, helping to evaluate how well the fetus handles the stress of contractions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal movement: This is a component of the BPP, assessing the number of fetal movements.

 

Option B. Fetal breathing: This is a component of the BPP, evaluating the presence of fetal breathing movements.

 

Option C. NST: The Non-Stress Test is a key component of the BPP, measuring fetal heart rate reactivity to movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Contraction Stress Test is not a component of the fetal biophysical profile.

 

Ref: Page no 122, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine US scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 126 mg/dL

 

Overt diabetes in a patient is diagnosed based on specific blood glucose levels. The criteria for diagnosing overt diabetes are:

 

  • Fasting blood sugar: ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • Random blood sugar: ≥ 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c: ≥ 6.5%

 

During pregnancy, maternal hyperglycemia, especially during the first trimester when organogenesis occurs, increases the risk of fetal congenital malformations, including cardiac malformations. This is particularly true for women with pre-gestational diabetes, not gestational diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 106 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 106 mg/dL does not meet the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option C. 116 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 116 mg/dL is higher than normal but still below the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option D. 130 mg/dL: This is incorrect. Although higher than the threshold, the minimum level to suspect overt diabetes is 126 mg/dL, not 130 mg/dL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Overt diabetes in pregnancy is diagnosed with a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dL, and maternal hyperglycemia.

choices.text: Beta HCG and PAPP-A
Unconjugated estradiol and PAPP-A
AFP and Inhibin A
AFP and Beta HCG

questions.text: Which test is used for screening Down’s syndrome in the first trimester? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Beta HCG and PAPP-A

 

In the first trimester, screening for Down’s syndrome involves measuring two specific analytes: human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A). In cases of Down’s syndrome, the first-trimester serum levels of free β-hCG are typically elevated (around 2.0 MoM), while PAPP-A levels are lower (around 0.5 MoM). These markers are effective in detecting fetal Down’s syndrome, particularly when combined with the nuchal translucency (NT) measurement or second-trimester analytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Unconjugated estradiol and PAPP-A - This combination is not used for first-trimester screening of Down’s syndrome.

 

Option C. AFP and Inhibin A - These markers are typically used in second-trimester screening.

 

Option D. AFP and Beta HCG - While these markers are useful in certain screenings, they are not the primary markers for first-trimester Down’s syndrome screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

First-trimester screening for Down’s syndrome primarily involves measuring Beta hCG and PAPP-A levels.

questions.text:
A couple already has 3 children and has been trying for another one for the last 1 year. However, the husband is diagnosed with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Which of the following is/are true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Low FSH, low LH
  2. High FSH, low LH
  3. Oligospermia
  4. Low prolactin
  5. Low testosterone
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 5

 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is a condition where there is decreased production of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland, leading to decreased stimulation of the testes and consequent reduced production of sex hormones such as testosterone. This results in:

 

1. Low FSH, low LH: In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, both follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) are low due to inadequate stimulation from the pituitary gland.

 

3. Oligospermia: Reduced levels of FSH and LH lead to decreased stimulation of the testes, which can result in reduced sperm production and oligospermia (low sperm count).

 

5. Low testosterone: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leads to reduced levels of testosterone because the testes are not adequately stimulated by FSH and LH.

 

The following are not true for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism:

 

2. High FSH, low LH: This pattern is more characteristic of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (primary testicular failure) rather than hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

4. Low prolactin: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is typically associated with normal or high levels of prolactin if there is an underlying pituitary issue. Low prolactin is not a characteristic feature of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, both FSH and LH levels are low, testosterone levels are low, and oligospermia is often present.

 

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Previous ectopic pregnancy
Previous history of abortion

questions.text: Which of the following would be considered as an absolute contraindication for insertion of copper T to a patient? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Unmotivated patient

 

Inserting a copper T intrauterine device (IUD) requires the patient to be motivated and consent to the procedure. An unmotivated patient or one who does not consent should never undergo the procedure. This is because the successful use of an IUD requires patient understanding, willingness to comply with follow-up care, and adherence to guidelines for managing any potential side effects or complications.

 

Absolute contraindications for the use of copper IUDs include:

 

  • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
  • Post-abortal sepsis, puerperal sepsis, current pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), or genital tuberculosis
  • Cancers such as endometrial cancer, cervical cancer, and gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
  • Large fibroids distorting the uterine cavity or Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Menorrhagia: While menorrhagia is a relative contraindication, as the copper IUD can exacerbate heavy menstrual bleeding, it is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option C. Previous ectopic pregnancy: A history of ectopic pregnancy is a consideration but not an absolute contraindication for copper IUD use.

 

Option D. Previous history of abortion: A previous history of abortion is not an absolute contraindication for the insertion of a copper IUD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An unmotivated patient or one who does not consent is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of a copper T intrauterine device (IUD).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 480

choices.text: 1st trimester USG is the best assessment
Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period
In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG
Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the period of gestation calculation: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

 

  • Gestational age or period of gestation (POG) refers to the duration of pregnancy calculated from the first day of last menstrual period
  • Calculating the EDD:
    • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
    • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day)
      • Add 9 months + 7 days
      • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
      • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer
    • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND
      • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
      • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1st trimester USG is the best assessment: Correct, because the 1st trimester USG provides the most accurate dating method.

 

Option C. In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG: Correct, because calculating gestational age in IVF pregnancies relies on the day of embryo transfer or fertilization.

 

Option D. Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester: Correct, because CRL is the best measure for assessing the period of gestation in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg, Dutta’s 108, 109, textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg127

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stress incontinence

 

Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by the involuntary leakage of urine due to increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as during coughing, sneezing, or physical exertion. It is commonly seen in women with utero-vaginal prolapse, where the support structures of the pelvic floor are weakened, leading to bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Overflow incontinence: Overflow incontinence occurs when the bladder cannot empty properly, leading to frequent or constant dribbling of urine. It is usually secondary to an obstruction, such as an enlarged prostate in men or severe prolapse in women causing a kink in the urethra. This condition does not typically present with leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure.

 

Option B. Urge incontinence: Urge incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine accompanied by or immediately preceded by a sudden, intense urge to urinate. This type of incontinence can be due to overactive bladder syndrome, where there is involuntary contraction of the bladder muscles.

 

Option D. Neurogenic bladder: Neurogenic bladder refers to a dysfunction of the urinary bladder due to a central or peripheral nervous system pathology. This can result in various types of incontinence, including both overflow and urge incontinence, depending on the nature of the neurological impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by involuntary leakage of urine due to increased intra-abdominal pressure and is commonly seen in women with utero-vaginal prolapse.

 

Ref: Page no 597, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Mandatory episiotomy
Manual perineal support and warm compresses
Maintain head in deflexion and deliver
Deliver in lithotomy position only

questions.text: Which of the following is recommended by the WHO for the management of the second stage of labor? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual perineal support and warm compresses


The WHO guidelines for managing the second stage of labor emphasize techniques to reduce perineal trauma and enhance maternal comfort. The use of manual perineal support and warm compresses is recommended to protect the perineum during delivery and reduce the incidence of severe perineal tears.

 

  • Manual Perineal Support and Warm Compresses:
    • Manual Support: Hands-on guarding of the perineum during delivery helps control the speed of delivery and reduces the risk of severe perineal tears.
    • Warm Compresses: Applying warm compresses to the perineum can help relax the tissues and make them more pliable, further reducing the risk of tearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mandatory Episiotomy: Not Recommended: Routine episiotomy is no longer recommended by the WHO. It is only indicated in specific cases where it is necessary to expedite delivery for the safety of the mother or baby.

 

Option C. Maintain Head in Deflexion and Deliver: Not Recommended: The recommendation is to allow the fetal head to assume the most optimal position for delivery rather than intentionally maintaining deflexion, which may hinder the delivery process.

 

Option D. Deliver in Lithotomy Position Only: Not Recommended: The WHO supports a variety of birthing positions based on the mother’s preference and comfort. Restricting delivery to the lithotomy position is not recommended; instead, women should be encouraged to choose their preferred position.

 

Educational Objective:


Manual perineal support and warm compresses are recommended by the WHO to reduce perineal trauma during the second stage of labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface
﻿﻿﻿Bacteria engulfed by macrophages
﻿﻿﻿Neutrophil engulfed bacteria
﻿﻿﻿Bacteria arranged in clusters

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

 

The microscopic finding described is consistent with "clue cells," which are a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis (BV). Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that are covered with a stippled appearance due to bacteria adhering to their surface. This attachment creates a poorly defined border on the cell. Clue cells are significant in diagnosing bacterial vaginosis because they are a reliable indicator of this condition. For a diagnosis of BV, at least 20 percent of epithelial cells in a wet mount preparation should appear as clue cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacteria engulfed by macrophages: This finding is more indicative of an inflammatory response and is not characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. It is more commonly associated with other types of infections or inflammatory conditions.

 

Option C. Neutrophil engulfed bacteria: This description is associated with acute bacterial infections or inflammation but not with bacterial vaginosis, where clue cells are the key finding.

 

Option D. Bacteria arranged in clusters: While bacteria may be present in clusters in some infections, this description does not specifically identify the clue cells characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clue cells, which are epithelial cells with bacteria attached on their surface, are the most reliable microscopic indicator of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Measure CA 125 levels
Follow up after 6 weeks

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who has had 2 children through normal delivery presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen, with irregular menses. Per vaginal examination revealed a mass felt through the posterior fornix. A USG showed a clear ovarian cyst of size 5 x 5 cm. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follow up after 6 weeks

 

A clear ovarian cyst with minimal symptoms and size less than 8 cm in a woman of reproductive age group is most likely a functional ovarian cyst. The next best step in the management of this case is to follow up after 6-12 weeks and perform a repeat USG.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Functional Ovarian Cyst: In reproductive-aged women, a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm is likely functional.
  • Follow-Up: The recommended management is to follow up after 6-12 weeks with a repeat ultrasound to check if the cyst resolves on its own.
  • Indications for Further Intervention: Surgical treatment is warranted if there are worrying features, the cyst is greater than 8 cm, there are significant symptoms, or CA-125 levels are raised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measure CA 125 levels: CA 125 is a marker for epithelial ovarian tumors and is more relevant in postmenopausal women. It has limited role in premenopausal women with clear, simple cysts.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy: Surgical intervention such as laparoscopy is not immediately necessary for a 5 cm cyst unless there are concerning features or persistence after follow-up.

 

Option D. CT pelvis: CT scan is not typically indicated for initial assessment of a simple ovarian cyst detected on ultrasound.

 

Additional information:

 

  • OC Pills: Oral contraceptive pills have not been proven effective in treating simple ovarian cysts, though they are often used.
  • Simple Ovarian Cysts: Any simple ovarian cyst less than 5 cm without symptoms can be left alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a reproductive-aged woman with a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm and minimal symptoms, the best approach is to follow up with a repeat ultrasound after 6-12 weeks, rather than immediate intervention.

 

Ref: RCOG greentop guideline number 62 , Williams textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg217

choices.text: Inhibition of ovulation
Increasing the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH)
Thickening of cervical mucus

questions.text: A 24-year-old medical student is attending a lecture on contraceptive methods. During the discussion, the student asks the instructor to explain how oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) prevent pregnancy. The instructor reviews the mechanisms by which OCPs work and addresses a common misconception about their function. At the end of the lecture, the instructor asks Which of the following is NOT a mechanism of action of oral contraceptive pills?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B. Increasing the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH)


Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) prevent pregnancy primarily by inhibiting the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus, which reduces the secretion of Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH) from the pituitary gland, thereby preventing ovulation. Additionally, OCPs work by creating a less favorable endometrial environment to prevent implantation, thickening cervical mucus to hinder sperm entry into the uterus, and altering the motility of the fallopian tubes, reducing the likelihood of sperm and ovum meeting. The misconception that OCPs increase GnRH release is incorrect; they actually inhibit it, which is a crucial aspect of their contraceptive action.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Inhibition of ovulation: OCPs suppress the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, effectively preventing the hormonal cascade that leads to ovulation.

 

Option C. Thickening of cervical mucus: By increasing the viscosity of cervical mucus, OCPs make it more challenging for sperm to penetrate and reach the egg, contributing to their contraceptive effectiveness.

 

Option D. Altering tubal motility: OCPs impact the motility of the fallopian tubes, slowing down the transport of both sperm and eggs, which further reduces the chances of fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:


Oral contraceptives prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation, thickening cervical mucus, altering tubal motility, and maintaining a less receptive endometrium. They do not increase the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH); rather, they inhibit it, which is central to their effectiveness in preventing conception.

choices.text: Malformations
Polyhydramnios
Fetal Macrosomia

questions.text: All the followings are seen in Gestational Diabetes Mellitus except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malformations

 

Congenital malformations are not typically seen with Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM); they are more associated with pre-existing overt diabetes mellitus. When diabetes is present and uncontrolled in the first trimester, particularly with an HbA1C greater than 10%, there is a higher risk of congenital malformations. The most commonly affected system is cardiac, with Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) being the most common anomaly. A very rare but characteristic anomaly associated with severe diabetes is Mermaid syndrome (sirenomelia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios, characterized by an Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) greater than 25 or a Single Deepest Pocket (SDP) greater than 8, is common in pregnancies complicated by GDM. It results from increased fetal urination due to hyperglycemia.

 

Option C. Fetal Macrosomia: Fetal macrosomia, defined as a birth weight greater than 4 kg, is a common complication of GDM. It is associated with excessive fat deposition, particularly around the shoulders, increasing the risk of shoulder dystocia during delivery.

 

Option D. Neonatal Hypoglycemia: Neonatal hypoglycemia, with blood glucose levels less than 45 mg/dl, is common in infants of mothers with GDM, especially if maternal blood sugar levels were unstable during labor. This occurs because the fetus produces excess insulin in response to maternal hyperglycemia, leading to low blood sugar levels after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital anomalies are not typically seen with Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM); they are associated with pre-existing overt diabetes mellitus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 2787

choices.text: Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days
Admit and observe
Follow-up with beta-HCG

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test came with complaints of lower abdominal pain, moderate bleeding PV. She was hemodynamically stable. On ultrasound, there was no gestational sac in the uterus. Ovaries were normal and no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follow-up with beta-HCG

 

The patient presents with symptoms that could indicate either an ectopic pregnancy or an early miscarriage. The absence of a gestational sac in the uterus on ultrasound at 6 weeks' gestation warrants further investigation to determine the location and viability of the pregnancy. The most appropriate next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Ectopic Pregnancy vs. Early Miscarriage: The differential diagnosis includes both ectopic pregnancy and early miscarriage.
  • Serial Beta-HCG Measurement: Beta-HCG levels typically double every 48-72 hours in a normal early intrauterine pregnancy. An abnormal rise or plateau in beta-HCG levels may indicate an ectopic pregnancy or a failing pregnancy.
  • Ultrasound Follow-up: In combination with beta-HCG monitoring, follow-up ultrasounds can help determine if a gestational sac becomes visible in the uterus or elsewhere.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days: Declaring a complete abortion without further investigation is premature and may miss an ectopic pregnancy, which can have serious complications.

 

Option B. Admit and observe: While observation is important, serial beta-HCG levels provide critical information that can guide further management decisions.

 

Option C. Diagnostic laparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure and is not the first step in stable patients without definitive evidence of ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, a positive pregnancy test, and no gestational sac visible on ultrasound, the next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels to differentiate between an early intrauterine pregnancy, an ectopic pregnancy, and a miscarriage.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 356

questions.text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sheehan’s syndrome

 

  • The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome.
  • When postpartum hemorrhage causes vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels (pituitary apoplexy) and panhypopituitarism. It is characterized by:
    • Lactation failure - due to prolactin deficiency
    • Amenorrhea - due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
    • Loss of sexual and axillary hair
    • Hypothyroidism - due to decreased TSH secretion
    • Adrenal insufficiency - due to low ACTH

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rotor Syndrome: Also known as Rotor type hyperbilirubinemia, is an autosomal recessive disease and a rare cause of mixed direct (conjugated) and indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia. The disease is characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice due to chronic elevation of predominantly conjugated bilirubin

 

Option C. Prolactinoma: This will not present lactation failure. Instead, there will be galactorrhea and symptoms like headache, luring of vision due to pressure effects of the prolactinoma.

 

Option D. Acromegaly: It is a disorder that results in excess growth of certain parts of the human body. It is caused by excess growth hormone (GH) after the growth plates have closed. The initial symptom is typically enlargement of the hands and feet. There may also be an enlargement of the forehead, jaw, and nose. Other symptoms may include joint pain, thicker skin, deepening of the voice, headaches, and problems with vision. Complications of the disease may include type 2 diabetes, sleep apnea, and high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan’s syndrome is characterized by postpartum hemorrhage leading to vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels, resulting in panhypopituitarism with symptoms like lactation failure and amenorrhea.

 

Ref: Page no 458, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Granulosa cell tumor

questions.text: A patient with an adnexal mass underwent surgery, and the following tumor was removed. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mature teratoma

 

The tumor described contains hair, teeth, and ovarian tissue, which are characteristic features of a benign teratoma, also known as a dermoid cyst. Benign teratomas are typically cystic and can contain various tissues such as hair, sebaceous material, and tooth structures. They are usually found in young women during their reproductive years and are often unilocular cysts with a wall lined by skin-like structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dysgerminoma - Dysgerminomas are usually solid tumors with a different histological appearance, characterized by large vesicular cells with clear cytoplasm and centrally placed nuclei.

 

Option C. Granulosa cell tumor - These tumors typically present with different histological features and do not contain hair, teeth, or other differentiated tissues.

 

Option D. Mucinous adenocarcinoma - This type of tumor is characterized by mucin-producing epithelial cells and does not typically contain hair or teeth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mature teratomas, or dermoid cysts, are characterized by the presence of differentiated tissues such as hair, teeth, and sebaceous material, making them identifiable upon gross examination

choices.text: Remove placenta and reposition the uterus
Put uterus inside without removing the placenta
Shift to OT and insert the uterus back

questions.text: A patient has just delivered a full-term baby and developed uterine inversion with the placenta still attached. What is the immediate next step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

 

Immediate management of uterine inversion involves repositioning the uterus before removing the placenta to prevent severe bleeding and shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to massive hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Shift to OT and insert the uterus back: Immediate manual repositioning is crucial before shifting to an operating theatre.

 

Option D. Start Oxytocin: Oxytocin is used after the uterus is repositioned to encourage contraction, not before.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of uterine inversion, the uterus should be repositioned with the placenta still attached to avoid significant bleeding, followed by medical management for uterine contraction.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lichen Sclerosus

 

The given image shows Lichen Sclerosus.

 

  • Lichen Sclerosus usually presents in postmenopausal women. Lichen sclerosus is one of the common dermatoses to affect the ano‐genital skin
  • The presenting symptom is usually itching, which is often severe and distressing. Patients may also complain of discomfort and dyspareunia if there is introital narrowing Perianal involvement frequently manifests as a figure-8 shape.
  • White, atrophic papules with abnormal anatomy distortion are the typical appearance. These papules may coalesce into plaques.
  • It is possible for introital stenosis, clitoral concealment, labia minora regression, and urethral obstruction to occur. A biopsy is required to rule out cancer.
  • Topical corticosteroids remain the first line of treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget Disease: Usually manifests as red, scaly, and crusty patches on the vulvar skin as shown in the image below.

 

 

It is often associated with an underlying malignancy. It does not present with white atrophic papules as shown in the question.

 

Option C. Lichen Planus:

 

Presents with purplish, flat-topped, itchy papules and plaques, often with a reticular pattern on mucous membranes, not typically white atrophic papules.

 

Option D. Angioma of Vulva:

 

This would present as a benign growth of small blood vessels and would be red and vascular in appearance as shown below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When encountering white atrophic papules and plaques on the vulva that may coalesce and distort the vulvar anatomy, lichen sclerosus should be considered as a primary diagnosis.

 

Premalignant lesions of vulva:

 

  • Vulvar Intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN)
  • Paget’s disease
  • Lichen sclerosus
  • Condyloma acuminata
  • Bowen disease (Erythroplasia of Queyrat)

 

Ref - William’s gynecology 4th edition Page no 92-100, 688

Shaw’s textbook of gynecology, 17th edition Page no 323, 473-475

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6298145/

questions.text: Type I collagen is not seen in? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Elastic cartilage

 

Elastic cartilage, as the name suggests, is more elastic than other types of cartilage. This is due to the presence of elastic fibers interspersed with the cartilage cells (chondrocytes).

 

The primary collagen in elastic cartilage is Type II collagen, not Type I.

 

Additionally, the elastin present in this cartilage gives it a yellowish appearance and makes it flexible. Examples of elastic cartilage include the external ear (auricle) and the epiglottis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone: Bone tissue primarily consists of Type I collagen. This collagen provides a framework upon which hydroxyapatite (a crystalline structure made of calcium and phosphate) can deposit, giving bones their characteristic rigidity and strength. Type I collagen provides the bone with some flexibility and tensile strength, which helps to prevent fractures.

 

Option B. Ligament: Ligaments, which connect bone to bone, are primarily composed of Type I collagen. This gives ligaments their tensile strength and ability to withstand pulling forces. The presence of Type I collagen in ligaments helps in maintaining joint stability.

 

Option C. Aponeurosis: An aponeurosis is a flat, sheet-like tendinous structure that attaches muscle to bone or other tissues. Like tendons, aponeuroses primarily contain Type I collagen. This allows aponeuroses to transmit muscular forces effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

List of types of collagens in various tissues:

choices.text: Cry of baby in the womb
Infection of vagina
Infection of uterus
Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cry of baby in the womb

 

  • Vagitus uterinus is the term used to describe the cry of a baby in the womb. It is a rare phenomenon but can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry, allowing the baby to make crying sounds while still in utero.
  • Vagitus vaginus is the term for the cry of the baby in the vagina, which can be heard during delivery.
  • Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis.
  • Infection of the uterus may affect its layers, leading to conditions such as endometritis (infection of the endometrium), myometritis (infection of the myometrium), and perimetritis (infection of the perimetrium).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infection of vagina: Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis, which is not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option C. Infection of uterus: Infection of the uterus can lead to endometritis, myometritis, or perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option D. Infection of both vagina and uterus: Infection of both the vagina and uterus involves conditions such as vaginitis and endometritis/myometritis/perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a baby in the womb, which is a rare phenomenon that can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry.

questions.text: A patient has Bilateral right sided loss of vision. What is the most likely site of lesion. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

Given the description of "Bilateral right sided loss of vision," the most likely site of the lesion would be the  Left optic tract. This type of visual field loss is consistent with the right visual field information being interrupted after the optic chiasma, which would affect the right visual field in both eyes.The optic tracts carry visual information after it has crossed at the optic chiasma. A lesion in the left optic tract would lead to a loss of vision in the right visual field of both eyes (homonymous hemianopia). This is because the left optic tract carries information from the right half of the visual field of each eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Optic Tract: Similarly, a lesion in the right optic tract would cause a loss of vision in the left visual field of both eyes. This is also homonymous hemianopia, but on the opposite side of the visual field loss compared to a left optic tract lesion.

 

Option C. Optic Chiasma: A lesion at the optic chiasma can cause various types of visual field defects. The most common is bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) halves of the visual field in both eyes. This typically occurs with pituitary tumors that compress the chiasma from below.

 

Option D. Optic Radiation: The optic radiation carries visual information from the thalamus to the visual cortex. A lesion in the optic radiation can also lead to homonymous hemianopia. The specific location within the optic radiation (e.g., Meyer's loop) can lead to more specific deficits like a superior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the visual pathway is critical for localizing lesions based on patterns of visual field loss. Lesions at different points along the visual pathway (e.g., optic nerves, chiasma, tracts, or radiations) will produce characteristic visual field defects. This knowledge is used to guide further diagnostic testing and management, which may include imaging studies like MRI or CT scans to visualize the lesion and determine its cause.

choices.text: Enoxaparin
Lepirudin
Fondaparinux
Dabigatran

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulant requires coagulation profile monitoring? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

 

  • Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that typically requires regular monitoring of anticoagulant effect via activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).
  • Enoxaparin (a low molecular weight heparin), Fondaparinux (a synthetic pentasaccharide), and Dabigatran (a direct thrombin inhibitor) generally do not require regular monitoring in most patients, although there may be specific clinical situations where monitoring is needed.

choices.text: Class I
Class II
Class III

questions.text: Dofetilide belongs to which class of anti-arrhythmic drugs? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Class III

 

Dofetilide is a class III anti arrhythmic drug that works by blocking K+ channels. The other class III anti arrhythmic include Amiodarone, Ibutilide, Sotalol and bretylium.

 

The side effect is QT prolongation/Torsades de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class I: These are sodium channel blockers.

 

Option B. Class II: These are beta-blockers.

 

Option D. Class IV: These are calcium channel blockers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class III drugs include:

B: Bretylium

I: Ibutilide

N

D: Dofetilide

A: Amiodarone

S: Sotalol

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of asthma and sinusitis. On looking into his medical records, you notice this has been attributed to Samter's triad. Which drug should be avoided in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

In a patient with Samter's triad, aspirin should be avoided as he will have aspirin intolerance.

 

Samter's triad is also known as aspirin-induced asthma or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It consists of:

 

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

 

Aspirin and COX – 1 inhibitors can exacerbate asthma hence they should be avoided. Rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur.

 

The provocative challenge test with aspirin or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is the only diagnostic method.

 

Aspirin desensitization is an important therapeutic option in patients with ST, especially in those patients suffering from recurrent NPs, anosmia, and overdependence on systemic corticosteroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cotrimoxazole and Option B. Co-amoxiclav: These are antibiotics used to treat bacterial infections, including sinusitis, and do not affect COX-1 activity.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol: An antibiotic that is generally used for serious infections where other antibiotics are not suitable. It does not interact with the COX-1 pathway.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients diagnosed with Samter's triad, it is crucial to avoid aspirin and other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1, as these can trigger severe respiratory and nasal symptoms. Effective management involves identifying safe medications for pain and inflammation and regularly monitoring the respiratory and nasal health of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 193, 194

choices.text: Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen and progesterone
Gonadotropin therapy to induce puberty
Regular monitoring of gonads with ultrasound

questions.text: A 18-year-old girl presents to the clinic with concerns of primary amenorrhea and lack of breast development. On physical examination, she is noted to have Prader 3 genitalia, indicating significant virilization with an increased phallic size and partial labioscrotal fusion. Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated levels of Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH). Further imaging with pelvic ultrasound reveals Mullerian structures, but the gonads are poorly visualized. A karyotype analysis shows 45, XO/46, XY mosaicism. Given these findings, what would be the next best step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B. Bilateral gonadectomy


The patient has gonadal dysgenesis with virilization, characterized by the presence of a Y chromosome and dysgenetic gonads. This condition carries a high risk of malignancy, including gonadoblastoma or dysgerminoma, due to the presence of Y chromosome material in the dysgenetic gonads. Bilateral gonadectomy is recommended to remove these gonads prophylactically at the time of diagnosis to prevent malignancy. The removal of gonads eliminates the risk of cancer and also addresses any androgen production that may contribute to virilization.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen and progesterone: This is an important step in managing this patient’s condition, but it should only be initiated after the gonads are removed. Estrogen therapy is necessary for the development of secondary sexual characteristics and bone health but does not mitigate the cancer risk posed by dysgenetic gonads.

 

Option C. Gonadotropin therapy to induce puberty: This is not appropriate because the primary concern in this patient is the high risk of malignancy associated with her gonads. Gonadotropin therapy will not address the underlying risk and is not used in cases of gonadal dysgenesis with a Y chromosome.

 

Option D. Regular monitoring of gonads with ultrasound: Ultrasound monitoring is insufficient in this context because it does not reliably detect early malignant transformation in dysgenetic gonads. Prophylactic removal is the safest course of action to prevent potential malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients with gonadal dysgenesis and a Y chromosome, such as those with 45,X0/46,XY mosaicism, bilateral gonadectomy is crucial to eliminate the significant risk of malignancy. Prophylactic removal of dysgenetic gonads is prioritized to prevent cancer, followed by hormone replacement therapy to manage pubertal development and long-term health.

questions.text: Identify the type of hypoxia according to given graph: (Brown graph is normal) (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anemic hypoxia

 

The given graph illustrates a 50% reduction in the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin, even though the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) stays within the expected range. This state is termed anemic hypoxia.

 

Anemic hypoxia occurs when there is a reduction in the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, usually due to a lower amount of hemoglobin, as seen in anemia. Despite normal levels of PO2, the overall oxygen content in the blood is diminished, leading to insufficient oxygen delivery to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stagnant hypoxia: This occurs when oxygen deficiency is due to poor blood circulation, not a reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. It is caused by issues like arterial obstruction or ischemia. The graph for stagnant hypoxia would show normal oxygen content in arterial blood but lower content in venous blood due to poor perfusion.

 

Option B. Histotoxic hypoxia: In this type, the cells are unable to utilize oxygen effectively, even though it is adequately supplied by the blood. This condition is typically caused by toxins like cyanide that impair cellular respiration. The graph for histotoxic hypoxia would show normal oxygen content in both arterial and venous blood since the issue is within the cells' ability to use oxygen, not the blood's ability to transport it.

 

Option C. Hypoxic hypoxia: This occurs when there is a generalized lack of oxygen in the body's tissues due to low oxygen in the blood, often seen at high altitudes or in conditions like COPD. The graph would show reduced PO2 along with decreased oxygen content in both arterial and venous blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Stagnant hypoxia: Oxygen deficiency due to poor blood circulation.
  2. Histotoxic hypoxia: Cells unable to utilize oxygen despite its availability.
  3. Hypoxic hypoxia: Generalized lack of oxygen in the body's tissues.
  4. Anemic hypoxia: Reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood due to low hemoglobin.

choices.text: Medroxy progesterone acetate

questions.text: Which among the following is an ideal treatment for a 55-year-old female with simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple hysterectomy

 

For postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia of the endometrium, the recommended treatment is a total hysterectomy. This approach is taken due to the increased risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma, especially given the presence of atypia and the patient's postmenopausal status.

 

  • Simple Hysterectomy: This involves the surgical removal of the uterus and is considered the ideal treatment for postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia to prevent the progression to cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: This is a progestogen treatment used primarily for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, especially in women who desire to preserve fertility. It is not the ideal treatment for atypical hyperplasia in a postmenopausal woman.

 

Option C. Levonorgestrel: The Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) is used for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia and as a conservative treatment for women wishing to preserve fertility. However, it is not the treatment of choice for atypical hyperplasia in a postmenopausal woman.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy: This is not a standard treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. It is typically reserved for more advanced or inoperable endometrial cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, the ideal treatment is a total hysterectomy to prevent progression to endometrial carcinoma.

 

Ref: Page no 330, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamezapine than oxcarbazepine , except ?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyponatremia

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. Oxcarbazepine induces this through its effect on renal handling of water by affecting antidiuretic hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rashes: Rashes are more common with carbamazepine due to its propensity to cause allergic skin reactions.

 

Option C. Blood dyscrasias: Blood dyscrasias, including agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia, are more associated with carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Hepatitis: Hepatitis and other liver dysfunctions are more often linked to carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While both carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause similar side effects, hyponatremia is notably more prevalent with oxcarbazepine.

choices.text: Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, induced labour
Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour
Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour
Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour

questions.text: Modified Robson's classification class 1 includes: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour

 

Class 1 of the Modified Robson's classification specifically includes:

 

  • Nulliparous: A woman who has never given birth before.
  • Singleton: A pregnancy involving only one fetus.
  • Cephalic: The fetal presentation is head-down.
  • ≥37 weeks: The pregnancy is at or beyond 37 weeks of gestation.
  • Spontaneous labour: Labour onset is spontaneous, not induced or via cesarean section.

 

This classification is used to categorize pregnant women for analyzing obstetric outcomes, interventions, and cesarean section rates. The Modified Robson’s classification is a system developed by the World Health Organization to help in understanding and comparing cesarean section rates and labor outcomes across different settings.

 

 

Robson’s 10 groups

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, induced labour: This option describes Class 2 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes nulliparous women with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and have induced labor or a cesarean section before labor.

 

Option C. Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour: This option describes Class 3 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes multiparous women (without previous cesarean section) with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and are in spontaneous labor.

 

Option D. Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour: This option describes Class 4 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes multiparous women (without previous cesarean section) with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and have induced labor or a cesarean section before labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class 1 of the Modified Robson's classification includes nulliparous women with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and are in spontaneous labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/259512/9789241513197-eng.pdf?sequence=1

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and eye pain. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. He has been treated both medically and surgically for the condition but showed no improvement. The following procedure incorporates a device to aid drainage. Identify the device.  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ex-Press™ implant

 

The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt).

 

It is a minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.

  • A tiny stainless-steel implant called Ex-PRESS is used to treat glaucoma.
  • It is implanted during a modified trabeculectomy underneath a scleral flap.
  • Hypotony-related complications are less common than with conventional trabeculectomy.
  • By creating a communication between the anterior chamber and the sub-space/sub-conjunctival Tennon's space, glaucoma drainage devices enable aqueous outflow.
  • While formerly only used in high-risk patients or after a failed trabulectomy, these devices are gaining popularity.
  • The commonly used devices are as follows:
    • ﻿﻿Shunts using episcleral explants
    • ﻿﻿Ahmed glaucoma valve- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Molteno implant- Polypropelene plate and silicone plate
    • ﻿﻿Baerveldt implant- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Mini-shunts
    • ﻿﻿Ex-Press™M Mini-Shunt- Stainless steel
    • ﻿﻿iStent®- Titanium

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ahmed Glaucoma Valve:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Contains a valve mechanism to prevent hypotony.
  • Popular for its ease of implantation and reliable outcomes.
  • Used in cases requiring controlled aqueous humor outflow but differs in design and function from the Ex-Press™ implant

 

Option C. Molteno Implant:

  • Made of polypropylene plate and silicone plate.
  • One of the earliest glaucoma drainage devices, offering various plate sizes.

 

Option D. Baerveldt Implant:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Designed to provide large surface area for filtration.
  • Requires ligation to prevent early postoperative hypotony.
  • Also used for glaucoma management

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant is a minimally invasive device used during modified trabeculectomy to enhance aqueous drainage and reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma. This implant is characterized by its stainless-steel construction and effectiveness in controlling glaucoma with fewer hypotony-related complications.

choices.text: Polycystic kidney disease

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to a fertility clinic with his spouse after 12 months of unprotected intercourse without any conception. He denies any history of erectile dysfunction or sexually transmitted infections. His medical history is unremarkable, and he has not undergone any surgeries. A semen analysis reveals azoospermia. A scrotal ultrasound shows the absence of bilateral vas deferens. The patient has no history of lung disease or gastrointestinal symptoms. The congenital absence of seminal vesicles and vas deferens is most commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cystic fibrosis

 

The congenital absence of the seminal vesicles and vas deferens, referred to as congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (CBAVD), is most commonly associated with cystic fibrosis (CF). CF is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene that impair the function of chloride channels. In men with cystic fibrosis, the absence of the vas deferens and seminal vesicles leads to obstructive azoospermia, where sperm are produced but cannot be transported out due to this obstruction. Some men with CBAVD may have few or no respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms, making infertility their primary or only presenting issue.

 

Pathophysiology: In CF, the absence of the vas deferens occurs due to abnormal CFTR gene function affecting the development of the male reproductive tract. As a result, the vas deferens fails to develop or is nonfunctional, leading to obstructive infertility.

 

Clinical Presentation: Men with CF and CBAVD often present with infertility without the characteristic respiratory or digestive issues commonly associated with CF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polycystic kidney disease: This genetic disorder is characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure over time. It does not affect the male reproductive system, and the vas deferens and seminal vesicles are typically present, making this an incorrect answer.

 

Option C. Young syndrome: Young syndrome is a condition associated with chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and obstructive azoospermia. While it does cause obstructive azoospermia, the vas deferens are typically present but blocked with thick mucus, unlike in cystic fibrosis where the vas deferens are congenitally absent.

 

Option D. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: In this condition, individuals with a 46,XY karyotype are phenotypically female due to resistance to androgens. These individuals have undescended testes and lack a uterus, but their reproductive tract does not develop normally. The absence of the vas deferens is not seen in this syndrome, making it an unlikely cause of the patient’s infertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis is associated with congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (CBAVD), a condition that leads to obstructive azoospermia and infertility in males. CBAVD may occur as an isolated feature of cystic fibrosis without the classical pulmonary or gastrointestinal manifestations of the disease.

questions.text: Identify the disorder with X-linked dominant inheritance: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

 

Rett syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.

 

Rett syndrome:

 

 

Other examples of XLD disorders include Vitamin D Independent Rickets, Aicardi Syndrome, Hypophosphatemic Rickets, Incontinentia pigmenti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD): Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is inherited in X linked recessive pattern. It is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene and predominantly affects boys, leading to progressive muscle weakness and wasting.

Option C. Huntington's disease: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, leading to motor dysfunction, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms.           

 

Option D. Tuberous sclerosis: Tuberous sclerosis / Bournville disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, characterized by the development of benign tumors in multiple organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder most commonly seen in girls, characterized by microcephaly, regression of motor milestones, developmental delay, and stereotyped movements.

questions.text: A patient on anti-tubercular therapy develops tingling sensation in the limbs. Which of the following when substituted can result from in improvement of symptoms? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyridoxine

 

This is a case of peripheral neuropathy that occurs in ATT therapy due to isoniazid (INH)

 

To treat this – Pyridoxine 10-25mg/day should be added to regimen.

 

High risk patients for peripheral neuropathy include- malnutrition, chronic alcohol dependence, diabetes, HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: While important for nervous system function, thiamine is not typically depleted by INH therapy.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Not directly related to the neurological side effects of INH.

 

Option D. Methylcobalamin: Though important for nerve health, it is not the primary vitamin depleted by INH therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation is essential for patients receiving isoniazid as part of their anti-tubercular therapy to prevent or manage peripheral neuropathy symptoms.

questions.text: Match the following Interleukins with their effector cells? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-C; 2-A; 3-B; 4-D  

 

Interleukins are a group of cytokines that play an essential role in immune responses by acting on different immune cells. Each type of interleukin can influence different target cells in specific ways.

 

  1. IL-4 - B cells: IL-4 is primarily involved in the activation and differentiation of B cells. It promotes the class switch to IgE production and plays a role in the TH2 immune response.
  2. IL-5 - Eosinophils: IL-5 is crucial for the growth and differentiation of eosinophils. It is involved in the pathogenesis of allergic diseases like asthma.
  3. IL-9 - Mast cells: IL-9 is involved in the proliferation of mast cells and enhances their function. It plays a role in allergic responses and asthma.
  4. IL-13 - Dendritic cells: IL-13 has multiple functions, including the modulation of dendritic cells, which are key antigen-presenting cells in the immune system. IL-13 also plays a significant role in allergic inflammation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child is presented with multiple times loose stools. He is managed with ORS. Glucose in ORS is absorbed via which transporter in GIT?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SGLT-1

 

Sodium-Glucose Transporter 1

 

  • SGLT-1 is a transporter protein located in the small intestine. It plays a crucial role in the absorption of glucose and sodium from the gut lumen into the enterocytes (intestinal cells). In the context of ORS, SGLT-1 facilitates the absorption of glucose, which helps in the rehydration process by increasing fluid absorption.

 

Glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestinal lumen into intestinal cell via secondary active transport using sodium dependent glucose transporter (SGLT-1). On the other hand, the glucose from the intestine cell in to blood at basolateral membrane is transported via passive transporter GLUT-2 (see fig)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT-2 (Sodium-Glucose Transporter 2): SGLT-2 is primarily found in the proximal renal tubules of the kidney and is responsible for the reabsorption of glucose from the urine. It is not involved in the absorption of glucose from the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. GLUT-4 (Glucose Transporter 4): GLUT-4 is a glucose transporter primarily found in muscle and adipose tissue. It is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake into these tissues and is not related to glucose absorption in the gut.

 

Option D. GLUT-2 (Glucose Transporter 2): GLUT-2 is a glucose transporter found in the liver, pancreatic beta cells, and the basolateral membrane of enterocytes. It is involved in glucose uptake by the liver and pancreas and is not the primary transporter for glucose absorption in the gut.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT-1 is the key transporter responsible for the absorption of glucose in the gastrointestinal tract. This mechanism is crucial in the management of conditions like diarrhea, where ORS containing glucose can help rehydrate the body by enhancing fluid absorption.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 538

choices.text: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient arrives at the emergency department with a history of stabbing injury to her arm. Upon examination, there is a noticeable hematoma, and the patient reports not feeling any radial or ulnar pulses in the affected arm. Imaging reveals a 3cm longitudinal tear in the brachial artery. The medical team is faced with deciding the best treatment option for the patient. Which option should they choose? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repair with great saphenous vein graft

 

  • The preferred treatment option for a patient with an injury to the brachial artery caused by a stab injury is to repair it with a great saphenous vein graft harvested from the patient's uninjured leg.
  • Repairing vessel injuries requires a tension-free approach.
  • The great saphenous vein is the most desirable graft for interposition grafts because of its elastic properties, similar diameter to that of an extremity artery, lack of thrombogenicity, and long-term patency.
  • Other graft materials that can be used include the cephalic vein, lesser saphenous vein, and prosthetic conduits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis: Primary arterial repair with end-to-end anastomosis is only possible if the repair can be performed in a tension-free manner. If the injured area is too long, an interposition graft is required.

 

Option C. Repair with prosthetic graft: Prosthetic grafts are only preferred when the native saphenous vein has been traumatized or when there is a size mismatch. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) graft is commonly used as a prosthetic conduit.

 

Option D. Repair with saphenous vein patch: Saphenous vein patch is used for the closure of arteriotomy site during carotid endarterectomies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Repair with a great saphenous vein graft is an appropriate choice in cases of brachial artery injury with extensive damage and vascular compromise, allowing for the restoration of blood flow to the arm. This surgical intervention should be performed urgently to prevent further ischemic complications in the affected limb.

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin
