Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue
Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet
Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin

questions.text: A HIV patient with fever, chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue

 

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. The image shows a blue background and red-stained oocysts, suggestive of modified acid-fast stain positive Cryptosporidium parvum.

 

The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (mZN stain) is a type of differential bacteriological stain used to identify acid-fast organisms, mainly Mycobacteria. Acid fast organisms are those which are capable of retaining the primary stain when treated with an acid fast (holding capacity).

 

Members of the Actinomycetes, genus Nocardia (N. brasiliensis and N. asteroides are opportunistic pathogens) are partially acid-fast. Oocysts of coccidian parasites, such as Cryptosporidium and Isospora, are also acid-fast. Hence, they can also be detected and identified through mZN staining procedure.

 

The reagents used for modified Ziehl–Neelsen staining are absolute methanol (for fixation), kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin (primary stain), acid alcohol (for decolorization), and methylene blue (counter stain).

 

Unlike the ZN-stain, the modified ZN stain does not require heating of the reagents. Kinyoun’s carbol fuschin has greater concentration of phenol and basic fuschin and does not require heating to stain properly. Heat is used as mordant (A mordant is a substance that increases the affinity of the cell wall for a stain by binding to the primary stain, thus forming an insoluble complex, which gets trapped in the cell wall). Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin: This combination is not used for modified acid-fast staining but is related to Gram staining.

 

Option C. Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet: This is incorrect as the proper primary stain for the modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain is Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin.

 

Option D. Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin: This combination is incorrect for modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain uses methanol for fixation, Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin as the primary stain, acid alcohol for decolorization, and methylene blue as the counterstain to detect acid-fast organisms like Cryptosporidium parvum.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with amenorrhea. On examination, she had normal genitalia & normal breast development. Her tests reveal a 5 alpha-reductase deficiency. What could be the probable diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male pseudohermaphrodite

 

  • The clinical vignette is suggestive of male pseudohermaphroditism.
  • In pseudohermaphroditism, the sex glands are of one sex while the external genitalia are of the opposite sex.
  • Male pseudohermaphroditism (male intersex) is an association of male gonads with female external genitalia.
  • In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend to the scrotum and ill development of the penis, thereby resulting in the female phenotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concealed sex: Criminals may conceal their sex to avoid detection by changing dress or by other methods. This is not relevant to the clinical scenario presented.

 

Option B. True hermaphroditism: In this condition, the glands of both sexes must be present in the same individual. Such cases are very rare. In most cases, the accessory sex gland is atrophic and lacks functional activity.

 

Option C. Female pseudohermaphrodite: The fault is at the level of an enzyme block of 17-hydroxyprogesterone (21 hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause) leading to defective production of sex steroids. There are features of virilization (clitoromegaly and the fused labioscrotal folds resemble a rudimentary scrotum). The ovaries may descend within the inguinal canal to lie in the labia majora simulating an inguinal testis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Male pseudohermaphroditism involves male gonads with female external genitalia. In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend and ill development of the penis, resulting in a female phenotype despite having male internal genitalia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology  6th edition pg 443

questions.text: All of the following supply the structure marked ‘E’ except? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Diagonal artery

 

The right ventricle is the marked object. The diagonal arterial supply does not reach it.

 

The anterior interventricular artery, which supplies the left ventricle, has a branch called the diagonal artery. Between 30 to 50 percent of the population has this.

 

The right coronary artery and its branches, including the marginal artery, provide the right ventricle with the majority of its blood.

 

One or two anterior right ventricular branches emerge from the anterior interventricular artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right coronary artery: This is correct in terms of not being an exception. The right coronary artery primarily supplies the right atrium and the right ventricle, including the structure marked as 'E', which is the right ventricle.

 

Option B. Anterior interventricular artery: This artery primarily supplies the interventricular septum and the anterior walls of both ventricles. Although it predominantly serves the left ventricle, it also sends branches such as the anterior right ventricular branches that can reach the right ventricle.

 

Option C. Marginal artery: This artery, a branch of the right coronary artery, specifically supplies the right ventricle, which is the structure marked as 'E'.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the vascular supply of the heart is crucial, especially in clinical settings dealing with coronary artery disease. The right ventricle is primarily supplied by the right coronary artery and its branches, including the marginal artery. The diagonal artery, a branch of the left coronary system (specifically the anterior interventricular artery), mainly supplies the left ventricle and does not contribute significantly to the blood supply of the right ventricle.

questions.text: A man in his 50s comes to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. During the examination, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is measured at 90/50mmg. Guarding is observed during a per abdomen examination. An erect abdominal X-ray is provided. What is the best management in this case based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exploratory laparotomy

 

Given clinical scenario of tachycardia, hypotension with abdominal guarding and X ray showing pneumoperitoneum is suggestive of hollow viscous perforation. The best management would be laparotomy and repair. The next step would be IV fluids.

 

Given the patient's severe abdominal pain, guarding during the physical examination, tachycardia, and hypotension, along with X ray findings suggest a perforation. An exploratory laparotomy would allow for direct visualization and treatment of the underlying cause. In emergent situations like this, a surgical exploration might be the most appropriate next step. Hence, OPTION C is the most appropriate choice among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG abdomen: Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen is a non-invasive imaging technique used to visualize abdominal organs. It may be used for a preliminary assessment of abdominal pain, but in the case of a patient with severe pain, hemodynamic instability (as indicated by tachycardia and hypotension), and guarding, accompanied by X ray showing free air, a USG would not add to the management.

 

Option B. IV fluids: Administering IV fluids can help stabilize the patient's blood pressure and is an essential immediate measure. However, fluids alone might not address the underlying cause of perforation.

 

Option D. Elective surgery: Elective surgery is a planned procedure that is done when a condition is not immediately life-threatening. Given the severity of the patient's symptoms and the potential for an acute abdominal catastrophe, waiting for an elective procedure is not appropriate in this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, the space within the abdomen that contains the intestines, liver, and other abdominal organs.

 

Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis:

 

Patients with a significant amount of free air in the peritoneal cavity due to organ perforation often present with severe abdominal pain, signs of peritonitis (like guarding and rebound tenderness), and systemic symptoms like fever or shock. An erect abdominal X-ray is a commonly used diagnostic modality to detect pneumoperitoneum. On the X-ray, free air under the diaphragm, or "free subdiaphragmatic air", is a classic finding.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Extravasation into venous system
﻿﻿﻿Bilateral cornual block

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral hydrosalpinx

 

The given HSG (hysterosalpingogram) film shows bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes, suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx. Hydrosalpinx is typically caused by the end result of repeated mild endo-salpingitis (inflammation of the fallopian tubes) by pyogenic organisms of low virulence but highly irritant.

 

The organisms involved include:

 

  • Staphylococcus
  • E. coli
  • Gonococcus
  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

During the initial infection, the fimbriae become edematous and in-drawn with the serous surface, adhering together to produce closure of the abdominal ostium. The uterine ostium gets closed by congestion. This results in the secretion being pent up, causing the tube to distend. The distension is marked more in the ampullary region than in the more rigid isthmus. As the mesosalpinx is fixed, the resultant distension makes the tube curled and look 'retort'-shaped. The wall is smooth and shiny, containing clear fluid inside, which is usually sterile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extravasation into venous system: This would show contrast leaking into the venous system and not confined to the Fallopian tubes.

 

Option C. Normal HSG: A normal HSG would show patent Fallopian tubes without distension or blockage.

 

Option D. Bilateral cornual block: This would show blockage at the cornua (the point where the Fallopian tubes enter the uterine cavity) without the dilated, fluid-filled appearance seen in hydrosalpinx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrosalpinx is characterized by bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes filled with clear fluid, often due to repeated mild infections causing obstruction and distension.

 

Ref: Page no 171, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A new diagnostic test for dengue is being evaluated using a Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) graph. As the curve transitions from the green region to the pink region, what is the most likely change in the test characteristics? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Both sensitivity and specificity increase

 

As the curve transitions from green to pink, both sensitivity and specificity experience an increase.

 

  • Sensitivity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease (cases)

 

Sensitivity = a/ (a + c) × 100 = TP/ (TP + FN) × 100

 

  • Specificity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease (healthy)

 

Specificity = d/ (b + d) × 100 = TN/ (TN + FP) × 100

 

 

 

As the curve transitions from green to pink, it increases the count of true positives and negatives while decreases the occurrences of false positives and negatives. Consequently, this shift results in increased sensitivity and specificity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On an ROC graph, a transition from one region to another indicating improved test performance generally means that both sensitivity and specificity are increasing.

questions.text: A child presents with erythematous scaly patches in the perioral region, mucosal ulcers, and impaired epithelial wound healing. What is the likely mineral deficiency associated with this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc deficiency

 

The clinical features of periorificial dermatitis and stomatitis in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, seen in zinc deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency - Most common micronutrient deficiency globally. It presents with iron-deficiency anemia. It presents clinically with pallor, fatigue, weakness, shortness of breath, light-headedness.

 

Option C. Calcium deficiency - Leads to rickets in children. Apart from clinical vignette of rickets there can be Muscle cramps and stiffness, Tingling and Numbness, Tetany.

 

Option D. Copper deficiency - Leads to anemia, growth retardation, defective keratinization and pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia, and neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency disorder- Acrodermatitis enteropathica

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with an abnormal Pap smear that revealed carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix, confirmed by colposcopy and biopsy. She has no visible macroscopic growth on examination, and her past medical history is unremarkable. She expresses concern about her fertility as she has not yet started a family. The gynecologist discusses the appropriate management options considering her age, fertility desires, and the stage of her disease. What is the recommended next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Conization


Carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix, also known as Stage 0 cervical cancer, involves the full thickness of the epithelial layer without invasion of the basement membrane. In a young woman like the patient described, conization is recommended because it serves a dual purpose: it provides a biopsy specimen to assess for any invasive disease and acts as a curative procedure by removing the lesion entirely. Conization is particularly suitable for women who wish to preserve fertility. If the woman’s family is complete or in elderly patients, simple hysterectomy could be considered as an alternative approach.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Radical Hysterectomy: Radical hysterectomy is not indicated for CIS, as it is an overly aggressive approach for a non-invasive condition. This option is reserved for more advanced stages of cervical cancer where there is clear invasion of surrounding tissues.

 

Option C. Chemoradiation: Chemoradiation is reserved for more advanced stages of cervical cancer, such as those with bulky tumors or evidence of spread beyond the cervix. It is not appropriate for early, non-invasive lesions like CIS.

 

Option D. Simple Hysterectomy: While simple hysterectomy could be considered in women who do not desire future fertility or are older, it is not the preferred option for younger patients who still wish to retain fertility. Conization is less invasive and sufficient in managing CIS.

 

Educational Objective:


Carcinoma in situ (Stage 0 cervical cancer) involves the full thickness of the cervical epithelium without basement membrane invasion. The preferred management in young women desiring fertility is conization, which serves both diagnostic and curative roles. More invasive procedures like radical hysterectomy or chemoradiation are reserved for more advanced disease stages.

questions.text: Calculate the Downe score of a newborn who has cyanosis which improves on giving oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, air entry markedly decreased, RR 40 per minute?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. It consists of five components: cyanosis, retractions, grunting, air entry, and respiratory rate (RR). Each component is scored from 0 to 2, with a total possible score of 10. Here's the breakdown for the given case:

 

 

Summing up the scores:


1 (cyanosis) + 1 (retractions) + 2 (grunting) + 2 (air entry) + 0 (RR) = 6

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. A score of 6 in this case indicates moderate respiratory distress, characterized by cyanosis that improves with oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, markedly decreased air entry, and a normal respiratory rate.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the colon are caused by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Entameoba histolytica

 

Flask shaped ulcers are classically seen in amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica.

 

 

The most typical form of amoebic infection, amoebic colitis, starts as a tiny region of necrosis of mucosa that may ulcerate. These ulcerative lesions may grow, develop ulcer edge undermining from trophozoite lytic action, and have a necrotic bed. Due to their structure, such chronic amoebic ulcers are called flask-shaped ulcers (narrow neck and broad base). In addition to the presence of Entamoeba histolytica trophozoites, the ulcer's edge exhibits an inflammatory response with an admixture of polymorphonuclear and mononuclear cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Giardia lamblia: Causes giardiasis, affecting the small intestine and leading to malabsorption and diarrhea but not flask-shaped ulcers.

 

Option C. Helicobacter pylori: Associated with gastric and duodenal ulcers, not typically flask-shaped or located in the colon.

 

Option D. Entamoeba vermicularis: Incorrect nomenclature; possibly meant to refer to a helminth such as Enterobius vermicularis, which causes pinworm infections and does not lead to ulcer formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entamoeba histolytica is the cause of flask-shaped ulcers in the colon, distinguishing it from other intestinal pathogens due to its invasive capabilities and the characteristic morphology of the ulcers it creates. Understanding these features helps in the differential diagnosis of dysentery and guides appropriate treatment and management strategies.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dimercaprol

 

Dimercaprol is a traditional chelating agent of choice for acute arsenic poisoning. Though now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Amongst the given choices, dimercaprol is best answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ipecac: Ipecac is rapidly acting anti-emetic. Earlier it was sometimes used to remove different types of unabsorbed poisons in GIT, but now it is no longer recommended due to limited benefits

 

Option B. Penicillamine: Though it can be used in arsenic, but not a preferred agent. It is preferred chelator for copper.

 

Option C. Activated charcoal: Not useful as it does not adsorb arsenic and other heavy metals

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Acute Arsenic poisoning

 

  • Hemodynamic stabilization for significant GI losses (vomiting and diarrhea)
  • Gastric lavage is done repeatedly with large amount of warm water and milk;
  • Chelating Agents
    • Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning
    • There are three chelating agents useful in acute arsenic poisoning:
      1. British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity.
      2. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally
      3. Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman who had an abdominal hysterectomy two years ago and is now experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting bile, high-pitched bowel sounds during examination. The presence of air within the biliary tree is seen on diagnostic tests. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of intestinal obstruction. Though adhesions could be the reason, the presence of air in biliary tree makes a diagnosis of gallstone ileus more likely.

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis, occurring due to the impaction of gallstones in the gastrointestinal tract. This occurs due to chronic gall bladder inflammation and formation of cholecysto-duodenal fistula (GB to duodenum). Through the communication, a gall stone may pass into the duodenum and then into small bowel.
  • Small gallstones may pass through the intestines spontaneously, but larger stones (2-5 cm) are more likely to cause obstruction, usually at the terminal ileum or ileocecal valve.
  • Symptoms may include acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of gastrointestinal obstruction, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice.
  • Diagnosis is typically made with a plain abdominal radiograph, which may show signs of obstruction, Pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree), and a gallstone in the intestines (RIGLER’S TRIAD).
  • Treatment involves surgical intervention, with a longitudinal incision made on the antimesenteric border to remove the gallstone.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Adhesive intestinal obstruction: This results from the formation of adhesions (bands of scar tissue) that can develop after surgery, which then bind the intestines together. These adhesions can pull the intestines out of place or create a kink or twist. The patient's history of an abdominal hysterectomy is suggestive of this, as post-surgical adhesions are a common cause of intestinal obstruction. However, the presence of air in the biliary tree does not fit with this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Ischemic enterocolitis: Refers to inflammation of the intestine due to reduced blood supply, often caused by blockage or constriction of the blood vessels that serve the intestines. Symptoms typically include sudden abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. While ischemic processes can cause pain and altered bowel sounds, the presence of pneumobilia on imaging is not consistent with ischemic enterocolitis.

 

Option D. Diverticulitis: Diverticulitis is the inflammation of one or more diverticula, which are small pouches that can form in the walls of the colon. Symptoms include lower left-sided abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits. While diverticulitis can lead to complications like abscesses, fistulas, or bowel obstructions, the specific presentation of vomiting bile and air within the biliary tree on imaging is not consistent with a primary diagnosis of diverticulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis characterized by the presence of air within the biliary tree, obstructive symptoms, and the formation of a cholecysto-duodenal fistula.
  • It typically presents with signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and is diagnosed through imaging, revealing pneumobilia and a gallstone in the intestines.

choices.text: FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8
FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient has grade III ASA. Which of the following post bronchodilator PFT findings requires further evaluation of the lung function of the patient? (INICET Nov 2021)

ASA- American Society of Anesthesiology

PFT- Pulmonary function test

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FVC- Forced vital capacity
questions.solution:
Ans. C. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7

 

This option shows a significant reduction in both FEV1 and the FEV1/FVC ratio. An FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7 is a clear indicator of obstructive lung disease. Combined with the reduced FEV1, this suggests significant lung dysfunction that requires further evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8: While these values indicate some reduction in lung function, they do not meet the threshold for a definitive diagnosis of obstructive lung disease. The FEV1/FVC ratio is still above the critical cutoff of 0.7.

 

Option B. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: These values suggest reduced lung function but not to the extent that is indicative of moderate or severe COPD. The FEV1/FVC ratio is below 0.8 but not yet at the critical threshold of 0.7.

 

Option D. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: While the FEV1 is below 0.8, the FEV1/FVC ratio is not at the critical threshold of 0.7, so it does not indicate significant obstructive lung disease requiring further evaluation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of lung function.

 

GOLD criteria for COPD is given as follows:

 

 

Abbreviations: COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; GOLD, Global Initiative for Lung Disease

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of the lung function.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 950

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency room with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following interventions is not typically performed in this situation? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelet transfusion

 

  • Platelet transfusion is not typically performed as an immediate intervention for variceal bleeding. Platelets are responsible for blood clotting, but variceal bleeding is primarily caused by the rupture of dilated blood vessels (varices) in the esophagus or stomach, which is related to portal hypertension.
  • Platelet transfusions are usually considered when a patient with liver cirrhosis has significant thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) or when there is an underlying bleeding disorder. However, they are not the primary treatment for variceal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arrange PRBC (packed red blood cell) transfusion: PRBC transfusion is often necessary to replace lost blood and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status. Active variceal bleeding can lead to significant blood loss, and transfusion of red blood cells is a crucial part of resuscitation.

 

Option C. IV Octreotide: IV Octreotide is commonly administered in cases of active variceal bleeding. Octreotide is a medication that helps reduce portal pressure by constricting blood vessels, including those in the varices. This can help control the bleeding until more definitive treatment, such as endoscopy or interventional radiology procedures, can be performed.

 

Option D. Urgent Endoscopy: Urgent endoscopy, typically performed within 12-24 hours, is a critical intervention in the management of variceal bleeding. During endoscopy, a gastroenterologist can identify the source of bleeding and perform interventions such as band ligation or sclerotherapy to stop the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of variceal bleeding:

 

  • Initial resuscitation: The first step in the management of variceal bleeding is to stabilize the patient with aggressive resuscitation measures, including airway management, fluid and blood product resuscitation, and correction of coagulopathy.
  • Endoscopy: Early endoscopy allows for the identification of the bleeding site and the application of endoscopic therapies such as band ligation or sclerotherapy.
  • Pharmacological therapy: Vasopressin and its analogs (such as terlipressin) are commonly used in the management of variceal bleeding to decrease portal pressure and reduce the risk of re-bleeding.
  • Antibiotics: Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended in patients with variceal bleeding to reduce the risk of bacterial infections, such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS): In patients with recurrent bleeding despite endoscopic and pharmacological therapy, TIPS may be considered to reduce portal pressure and prevent further bleeding.
  • Surgery: In rare cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to control variceal bleeding, particularly in patients with refractory bleeding or severe liver disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prokinetic? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diphenylmethane

 

Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic drug. It is a type of organic compound that is not used for the treatment of gastrointestinal motility disorders.

 

A prokinetic drug is a medication that increases gastrointestinal motility and promotes the movement of food through the digestive system. 5HT4 agonists, dopamine antagonists, and macrolides are all types of prokinetic drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5HT4 agonists stimulate the release of serotonin in the gut, which enhances gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option B. Dopamine antagonists block the action of dopamine in the gut, which can increase gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option C. Macrolides have antimicrobial properties and also act as motilin receptor agonists, which promote gastrointestinal motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic drug and is not used to treat gastrointestinal motility disorders. Prokinetic drugs include 5HT4 agonists, dopamine antagonists, and macrolides, which all act to enhance gastrointestinal motility.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, cannot hold a pen and he was not able to hold a paper between fingers. Which of the following sites given below is the probable cause of injury to the nerve in question? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 7

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient complaining of inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, not able to hold a pen and also not able to hold paper between fingers, all together suggests towards an ulnar nerve injury. The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle – structure marked as 7.

 

Given below is the labelling of the structures marked in the figure -

 

  1. Head
  2. Greater Tubercle
  3. Intertubercular Groove
  4. Deltoid Tuberosity
  5. Capitulum
  6. Trochlea
  7. Medial Epicondyle
  8. Olecranon Fossa
  9. Lateral Epicondyle
  10. Lesser Tubercle

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Head of Humerus: This area is not typically associated with isolated ulnar nerve injuries. Injuries here affect the axillary nerve.

 

Option C. 9: Lateral Epicondyle: The lateral epicondyle is more commonly associated with injuries affecting the radial nerve or conditions like lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow).

 

Option D. 4: Deltoid Tuberosity: This site on the humerus is typically associated with the attachment of the deltoid muscle. Injuries or issues here would more likely affect the deltoid muscle or the radial nerve dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tests for ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:

 

1. Card Test: This isn't a widely recognized test in the context of ulnar nerve pathology. However, in some practices, the card test might refer to asking the patient to hold a card (like a credit card) between their thumb and the side of their index finger. Difficulty or inability to do this due to a weak adductor pollicis muscle (innervated by the ulnar nerve) may suggest ulnar nerve dysfunction.

 

2. Claw Hand Deformity: This is seen in ulnar nerve injuries. In a typical ulnar claw hand, the 4th and 5th digits (ring and little fingers) are hyperextended at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexed at the interphalangeal (IP) joints. This occurs due to the loss of function of the lumbricals and interossei of the hand, which are innervated by the ulnar nerve.

 

3. Froment's Sign: This is a classic sign of ulnar nerve palsy. The patient is asked to hold a piece of paper between their thumb and the side of their index finger (pinch grip). If the ulnar nerve is compromised, the patient will compensate by flexing the thumb's IP joint to maintain grip strength, which is a positive Froment's sign. This indicates weakness or paralysis of the adductor pollicis muscle.

 

4. Wartenberg Sign: In ulnar nerve injury, there's unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi, which leads to abduction of the little finger. The patient will be unable to bring their little finger back to the side of the hand, leading to the "Wartenberg sign."

 

5. Palmaris Brevis Sign: This is a sign of ulnar nerve functionality. The palmaris brevis muscle is innervated by the ulnar nerve. Upon tapping or massaging the hypothenar eminence (palm side of the hand, base of the little finger), contraction of the palmaris brevis muscle can be observed as a twitching or dimpling. If present, it indicates that at least part of the ulnar nerve's function remains intact.
